div.head: Question 1
Whether there is some sine which is absolutely unforgivable
div.p:
Quaestio I
An peccatum aliquod sit simpliciter
irremissibile

VTRVM aliquod peccatum sit simpliciter irremissi
bile.

Et videtur quod sic. Quia pro omni peccato ri
missibili est orandum, vt dimittatur: sed quoddam est pec
catum, pro quo non est orandum, vt dimittatur, iuxta il
lud loan. dicitur, Est peccatum ad mortem, pro quo non
dico, vt oret quis.

Contra, illud malum non est simpliciter irremissibile
cuius radix, seu potentia est a Deo: sed potentia peccandi quo
cuque genere peccati est a Deo, vt infra patebit:ergo nullum
peccatum est simpliciter irremissibile. Hic primo videndum
est, vtrum sit aliquod peccatum in spiritum sanctum. Se
cundo vtrum huiusmodi peccatum sit irremissibile Et hoc
quantum ad distinctionem. 43 Tertio videndum est, vtri
omnis potentia peccandi sit 2: Deo. Quarto vtrum omnis
potentia dominandi sit a Deo. Et hoc quantum ad di
stinctionem vltimam, scilicet. 44. istius secundi libri.

RESOLVTIO.
Et si nullum quidem percatum ad diuinam potentiam relatum,
irremissibile dici possit, ex diuina tamen, & inspirata seriptura
nobis consiat quoddam esse crime in Spiritum sanctum satum,
quod sane propter ea irremissibile nuncupatur, quia nullam in
se causam annexam peccatum excusantem continet, licet peccam
li potentia a Deo tmnamauit.

div.head: Articulus 1
Utrum sit aliquod peccatum in spiritum sanctum
div.p:
ARTICVLVS I
Vtrum sit Aliquod peccatum in spiritum
ssnctum.

QVANTVM ad primum dico, quod plane & mani
fesse patet ex scripturis sacris, quoddam peccatum
esse, quod dicitur in spiritum sanctum. Patet enim hoc ex
Euang. Et ideo praesupposito tali peccato esse, duo sunt
videnda circa ipsum. Primo, scilicet quid sit peccatum in
spiritum sanctum. Secundo, quot sint peccata in spiri
tum sanctum,

Quo ad primum est aduertendum, quod vt patuit su
perius in primo lib hoc nomen spiritus sanctus quando
que accipitur essentialiter, & sic conuenit ipsi deitati, &
toti trinitati. Et sic dicitur, Spiritus est Deus, & eos, qui
adorant eum, in spiritu & veritate oportet adorare. Alio
modo personaliter: & sic solum dicitur de tertia persona
in diuinis, iuxta primum modum scriptura sacra videtur
accipere spiritum, cum dicitur esse peccatum in spiritum
sanctum Nam, vt sic, huiusmodi peccatum distinguitur con
tra blasphemiam illatam domino nostro Iesu Christo,
quo ad suam humanitatem: nam blasphemia contra dei
atem dicitur in scripturis irremissibilis, contra autem
humanitatem dicitur remissibilis. Vnde cum Iudaei
Christo blasphemiam intulissent dicentes, vorax est &
potator vini, & amicus publicanorum, & peccatorum, po
stea dixerunt blasphemiam contra virtutem suae deitatis
dicentes: hic non eiicit daemonia nisi in belxebub princi
pe daemoniorum Et ideo circa finem illius capituli sub
dit dominus noster lesus Christus dicens, Quicumque
contra filium hominis verbum dixerit, remittetur ei: qui
autem contra spiritum sanctum dixerit verbum, non re
mittetur ei, neque in hoc seculo, neque in futuro. Et isto
modo videntur loqui de peccato in spiritum sanctum do
ctores antiqui, scilicet Athanasius, Hylarius, Chrisosto
mus, Ambrosius, & Hicronymus. Moderni vero doctore,
appellant peccatum in spiritum sanctum, secundum quod
quis peccat contra appropriatum spiritus sancti, & vt spi
ritus sanctus accipitur personaliter, puta, prout quis pec
cat contra diuinam voluntatem, bonitatem, & clemen
tiam, quae appropriatur spiritui sancto.

De numero autem; & distinctione talium peccatorum
diuersi diuersimode loquuntur. Aliqui enim videntur d
tere, quod peccata in spiritum sanctum sint quattuor, sci
licet desperatio, praesumptio, & agnitae veritatis, & maxi
me veritatis fidei impugnatio, & fraternae gratiae proxi
mo collatae inuidentia, seu aemulatio. Aliqui, addunt ob
tinationem, & propositum numquam poenitendi: & sic
crunt sex. Aliij addunt peccatum ex certa malitia, quod
qmandoque dicitur peccatum ex electione, quandoque pecca
tum ex habitu, & finalem impoenitentiam, & sic erunt octo.

Distinctio autem horum fic haberi potest; quia quat
tuor possumus in proposito considerare, scilicet ipso
rum peccatorum medicum, medicinam, infirmum, & in
firmitatem.

Per comparationem igitur ad medicum accipitur des
peratio, & praesumptio: nam aliqui solum attendunt eius
iustitiam, nihil reputantes eius misericordiam, modo, quo
dixit Cavm, Maior est iniquitas mea, quam vt veniam me
rear. Et horum peccatum est desperatio. Isti autem sunt
calde ingrati, quod non attendunt, quam magna Dei miseri
cordia est, quod etiam ipsi in hoc mundo viuunt, & iam
in infernum non descendunt, & ideo non haberent neg
re diuinam misericordiam: sed deberent eam suppliciter
exorare. Vnde de tali ingratitudine videtur dicere bern
cum ait, Ingratitudo est ventus vrens, siccans fontem pie
tatis, veniam misericordiae, fluenta gratiae. Aliij attendunt
solum Dei misericordiam in nullo formidantes eius iu
stitiam, & istorum peccatum est praesumptio: nimis enim
praesumit, qui tanti regis iustitiam non formidat

Respectu medicinae, quae quidem medicina est fides &
gratia, sumuntur alia duo. Nam impugnantes fidei verita
tem, & inuidentes gratiae gratum facienti fratribus com
municatae, inutilem faciunt sibi medicinam suorum pec
ratorum, quae consistit in fide & gratia.

Ex parte vero infirmi, scilicet peccatoris, se tenent alia
duo: nam peccator ex hoc, quod omnino pertinaciter se
couertit ad commutabile bonum, dicitur obstinatus:: sed ex
hoc, quod omnino pertinaciter se auertit ab incommu
tabili bono dicitur impoenitens . non habere propositum
poenitendi, quo possit redire ad huiusmodi incommuta
bile bonum. Sed ex parte infirmitatis se tenent vltima
duo; nam peccatum ex electione, seu ex certa malitia est
ex habitu vitioso, qui est turpissima mentis infirmitas. Fi
nalis autem impoenitentia est huiusmodi infirmitatis, &
morbi cuiuslibet mortalis peccati maledicta creticatio
tendens in mortem aeternam.

Est tamen aduertendum, quod prima quattuor magis
proprie dicuntur esse peccata, cum sint distincta & de
terminata genera peccatorum secundum distinctam ma
teriam. Alia vero magis proprie possunt dici circumstan
tiae, vel sequelae peccatorum: quia quodlibet istorum non
habet materiam determinatam, sed applicabilia sunt ad
quodlibet genus mortalis peccati. In quolibet enim ge
nere peccati homo potest fieri obstinatus, & non habere
propositum consitendi vel poenitendi, & habitum vitio
sum acquirere & sine poenitentia finaliter mori, seu dece
dere. Et ideo quo ad hoc magis approbabo sententiam il
lorum doctorum, qui quattuor dicunt esse genera pecca
torum in spiritum sanctum,

div.head: Articulus 2
Utrum peccatum in spiritum sanctum sit irremissibile
div.p:
ARTICVLVS II.
Vtrum peccatum in spiritum sanctum sit
irremissibile

QVANTVM ad secundum articulum dico, quod
respectu diuinae potentiae nullum peccatum est
irremissibileÂ¬

1 Posset enim Deus, si vellet, remittere tam viuorum
quam mortuorum, tam daemonum, quam hominum pec
cata: sed vocando peccatum remissibile, quod derelin
quit aptitudinem, seu concernit habilitatem ad hoc, quo
remittatur, sic quodlibet peccatum in spiritum sanctum
potest dici irremissibile: nam quamuis peccatum ex igno
rantia, vel ex passionis impulsu, vel impotentia aliquate
nus excusetur, & per consequens concernat habilitatem
ad remissionem: tamen peccatum in spiritum sanctum
nullam habet causam annexam peccatum excusantem
sed solum aggrauantem; ideo nullam concernit aptitudi
nem ad sui remissionem.

2 Praeterea, sicut infirmitas corporalis dicitur : incu
rabilis, cum per ipsam sic disponitur infirmus, quod om
nem escam abominatur, & omnem medicinam abhorret
& refutat, iuxta illud psal. Omnem escam abominata est
anima eorum, & appropinquauerunt vsque ad portas mor
tis: Sic quia peccans in spiritum sanctum abhorret spiri
tualem medicinam, vt patet ex praecedentibus: ergo &c

Praeterea, nullum peccatum mortale dimittitur si
ne poenitentia: sed quodlibet peccatum in spiritum san
ctum aliquo modo facit peccatorem impoenitiuum: ergo
quodlibet potest dici irremissibile.

Dicunt autem quidam doctores in ista materia, quod
si vocetur peccatum in spiritum sanctum peccatum mor
tale cum finali impeonitentia, vt accipitur peccatum in spiri
tum sanctum a beato Augustino, sic simpliciter dicitur in
remissibile: quia numquam potest remitti, nec in vita ista
impediente fnali impoenitentia, nec in alia vita, quia in ea
non erit status remissionis: ergo &c

1 Sed istud non videtur esse verum: quia infinita potens
tia Dei non exhauritur magnitudine cuiuscumque pec
cati; ergo Deus omne peccatum potest remittere.

2 Praeterea, satis communiter dicitur ad preces Gre
gorii Traianum fuisse ab inferno liberatum, & ad agendum
poenitentiam de mortuis resuscitatum: & tamen planum
est, quod Traianus in multis peccatis mortalibus decessit
propter multas martyrum strages, quas fecit, & cum finali
impoenitentia decessit, quia si poenitentiam egisset, ante
quam decessisset, tunc pro suis peccatis non fuisset dam
natus, nec pro agenda poenitentia fuisset resuscitatus.

div.head: Articulus 3
Utrum omnis potentia peccandi sit a Deo
div.p:
ARTICVLVS III
Vtrum omnis potentia peccandi sit
a Deo.

QVANTVM ad tertium articulum dico, quod poten
tia peccandi est a Deo.

1 Quia omne ens est a Deo, potentia peccandi est ali
quod ens: ergo &c. Maior patet ex fide: quia sine ipso fa
ctum est nihil Probo minorem: quia quod purum nihil
est, nulla potentia est

2 Praeterea potentia benefaciendi est a Deo: ergo &
otentia peccandi. Antecedens patet. Consequentiam
probo: quia eadem est potentia merendi & demerendi;
quod probatur sic: quia potentia rationali possumus be
nefacere &, mereri, sed potentiae rationales sunt ad op
posita: eadem ergo potentia possumus malefacere & de
mereri, quod proprie est peccare.

3 Praeterea, sola voluntas est proprie potentia peccan
di, vt patet per Aug: 2. de lib. arbitrio, sed voluntas est a
Deo: ergo &c.

4 Praeterea, omne bonum est a Deo: sed potentiae ma
lorum sunt bonae, vt dicitur. 3. topi. ergo &c.

Sed quidam doctores circa istam materiam respondent
per distinctionem. Dicunt enim, quod potentia peccandi
potest dupliciter considerari. Vno modo, prout est princi
pium actus. Alio modo, vt potest deficere. Primo modo
est a Deo: quia, quicquid habet naturam entis positiui,
oportet, quod reducatur ad Deum, sicut ad causam. pri
mam. Sed secundo modo non est a Deo: quia defectibili
tas conuenit rei creatae ex eo, quod est ex nihilo, vt ait Dam.
esse autem ex nihilo conuenit rei creatae secundum se:
quia sibi derelicta tendit in nihilum, & per consequens
non poterit sibi conuenire ab alio, puta, a Deo.

1 Nam quod competit alicui ex se, non potest sibi com
petere ex alio.

Praeterea, ad idem arguunt quidam alij sic. Si poten
tia peccandi esset a Deo, hoc maxime esset pro tanto: quod
talis potentia esset ipsum liberum arbitrium: sed hoc
non, quia dicit Ansel. in de libero arbitrio, quod peccare
nec est libertas, nec pars libertatis.

3 Praeterea, si potentia peccandi esset a Deo, tunc ipsum
peccatum esset a Deo. Consequens est falsum. Probatio
consequentiae, quia actus est perfectior, quam potentia:
Dei autem perfecta sunt opera, vt dicitur in Deutero.

4 Praeterea, illud, cuius vsus est malus, ipsum quoque
est malum, vt dicitur 3 topic. & per consequens tale quid
non potest esse a Deo: sed vsus potentiae peccandi est ma
lus, quia vsus talis est ipsum peccare: ergo talis potentia
non potest esse a Deo.

Sed quamuis conclusionem elicitam ex prima parte
praedictae diuisionis reputem esse veram: tamen conclusio
elicita ex parte secunda, quae conclusioni per me posita
videtur repugnare, non videtur posse stare.

1 Quia defectus, qui non habet rationem mali, non
minus videtur esse a Deo, quam ille defectus, qui habet
rationem mali: sed defectus, qui habet rationem mali, est
a Deo, puta defectus poenalis: possibilitas autem deficien
di non habet rationem mali, quia omne malum, vel est
malum culpae, vel poenae: sed possibilitas deficiendi nec
habet rationem mali culpae, nec poenae, quia fuit in sta
tu innocentiae, & per consequens ante omnem culpam
& poenam

2 Praeterea, potentia deficiendi per corruptionem inest
rebus creatis curruptibilibus a Deo: ergo & potentia defi
ciendi per electionem quae est potentia peccandi inerit ipsis
rebus potentibus eligere ab ipso Deo. Antecedens pa
tet, quia illud quod necessario requirit ordo vniuersi, hoc
conuenit rebus a Deo; sed habere potentiam deficiendi
per corruptionem requirit ordo vniuersi: nam plantae non
possent nutriri, si terra non posset corrumpi: nec pari ratione
bestiae possent nutriri per plantas, nec homines per bestias.

3 Praeterea, quod creatura sit de nihilo, hoc habet ab
ipso Deo, sed ex hoc inest creaturae potentia peccandi,
quia est de nihilo, vt dicit praedicta opinio: ergo potentis
peccandi inest creaturae ab ipso Deo. Maiorem probo, quia
quicquid est causa alicuius affirmationis, hoc etiam est
causa negationis per se, & immediate consequentis ad ta
lem affirmationem: quicquid enim est per se causa, quod
aliquid sit sanum, hoc etiam est causa, quod tale quid non
fit aegrum: sed Deus est causa creaturae secundum omnem
entitatem posituam, quae est in creatura: ergo Deus est cau
sa, quod creatura sit de nihilo, & de nullo praesupposito,
cum ista negatiua per se, & necessario sequatur ad illam
affirmatiuam.

Et per hoc patet ad primam rationem, quia esse ex ni
hilo non competit creaturae ex se, sed ex Deo. Ad proba
tionem cum dicitur, quod creatura sibi derelicta tendit
in nihilum, dico, quod talis tendentiae sufficiens causa est
ipse Deus, non per sui influentiam & operationem: sed
er suae influentiae subtractionem: quia illud, quod per sui
influentiam est totalis, & perfecta causa alicuius entita
tis, & conseruationis eiusdem, illud per subtractionem sua
insiuentiae erit sufficiens causa, quare huiusmodi entitas
cadat in nihilum: sed Deus per suam influentiam est per
fecta causa omnis entitatis creatae, & conseruationis totius
creaturae, quae conseruatur in aliquo esse: ergo &

Ad secundum nego minorem. Ad probationem dicen
dum, quod quamuis peccare non sit libertas, posse tamen
peccare est in nostri arbitrii libertate: liberior tamen esset
nostra voluntas, si peccare non posset, quia maior est li
bertas beatorum, qui peccare non possunt, quam viatorum
qui peccare possunt

Ad tertium nego consequentiam. Ad probationem
dico, quamuis in bonis actus sit nobilior potentia, tamen
in malis est econuerso: nam peius est actu aegrotare, quam
posse aegrotare.

Alias inuenitur talis additio. Etiam potest dici, quod
licet peccatum non sit a Deo, tamen actus peccati est a
Deo, eo modo, quo dictum est.

Ad quartum dicendum, quod licet illud sit malum,
cuius vsus ita est malus, quod non possumus eo bene vti:
tamen cuius vsus est malus non necessario, sed ex eo, quod
cum possemus eo bene vti, abutimur eo, illud non est ma
lum, sed potest esse bonum, possumus enim etiam bonis
male vti, & hoc magis proprie abusus, quam vsus debet di
ci. Sed potentia peccandi, quae est liberum arbitrium, pos
sumus, si volumus bene vti resistendo vitiis, & prosequen
do virtutes: ergo &c

div.head: Article 4
Whether every power of dominating is from God.
div.p: ARTICLE IIII Whether every power of dominating is from God.

With respect to the fourth article there are two things that should be seen. First, whether every authority or power of dominion is from God. Second whether a believer ought to obey the dominion of an unbeliever or unbelieving prince.

With respect to the first I say that authority or rule is able to be considered in three ways: first in itself, second with respect to the manner in which someone acquires leadership, and third with respect to its use.
In the first way of understanding rule, every ruler is from God.
First because all good things come from God, but rulership considered in itself, since it is a type of order or ordered way of seeing is a significant good of the universe, therefore it is from God.

Second because every first is the cause of all the things that come after it, but God is the first ruler of the universe. The major premise is clear in II Metaphysics. The Minor premise is similarly clear in XII Metaphysics.

Further, anything that would have been in paradise, if human beings had remained in the state of innocence is from God or would have been from him, but rulership in the aforesaid mode would have been in paradise, therefore etc. The major is clear. I prove the minor because naturally there are lords who are strong in prudence and intellect, as is clear in the first book of the Politics. For on account of this a parent in some fashion has lordship over children, men have lordship over women, and humans have lordship over beasts. But likewise in paradise, one man would have been more than another with respect to their intellectual habits and acts, according to which one would have better complexion than the other because we say that those with soft flesh are skilled in the mind, but those with hard flesh are not so skilled, as is clear in II de anima, which is true when speaking about the softness coming from goodness or the rarity of complexion and from the abundance of phlegm as is the case among women. But in paradise one would be of greater complexion than another. This is clear because then, just as now according to the better conjunction of stars there would be a fetus conceived of a nobler complexion.

Perhaps it is said that there is not able to be dominion without servitude, but in paradise there would be no servitude. The major is clear because one of a pair of relatives is not able to be without the other, as is clear in the Categories and V Metaphysics. The Minor is also clear because servitude was only introduced on account of sin.

Further, every dominion uses some law with respect to its subjects, but the law is not imposed on the just, as the Apostle says, therefore since everyone in the state of innocence would have been perfectly just on account of original justice, which everyone would have had in paradise, therefore there would not have been law in paradise, nor consequently dominion. And this is confirmed because, as is clear through book 10 of the Ethics, it was necessary to instituted laws for those having the power to compel and this was only due to the rebellious and unjust. But in the state of innocence, no one was rebellious or unjust

I respond that dominion is able to be considered in two ways. In one mode, insofar as it concerns slavish fear which excludes love in the one subjected, and this is the despotic dominion which requires painful servitude which was introduced on account of sins of this type. And humans would not have had this type of dominion with respect to other humans in the state of innocence but only with respect to irrational animals. On account of this God said to the first parents, dominate the fish of the sea, and the birds of the air, and over all the animals which move on the earth. And later the Lord said to Noah and his sons, your fear and dread will be over all the animals of the earth. In the another mode, as it concerns mutual love. And this happens in two ways, think first of the free will, and this is the way of royal dominion, and this would have been suitable for fathers with respect to their children. Or secondly according to certain law, and this is political dominion which suits the one who excels in the city in comparison to other citizens, and in paradise this would have been appropriate to man over his wife since the man would have been superior to his wife according to certain laws promoting the good of matrimony; and it would also have been suitable in paradise to the more politically prudent over the less prudent, insofar as these would have instructed the others in those matters which would have been beneficial for them.

And through the above the response to the first objection is clear. To the second objection it should be said that among us there are three types of rulership (praelatio). The first is to teach subjects so that they might be directed more appropriately in their actions. The second is to defend subjects so that they are not oppressed by the unjust. And the third is to punish wicked subjects, so that they are corrected from their excesses. In the first mode, there would have been law and rulership in paradise, but not in the second and third modes. And in these later two senses the authority of the Apostle and the Philosopher should be understood.

Further, for the aforementioned conclusion I argue in this way. That which is suitable to humans according to right reason, this is also suitable to them from God or according to the divine order. But according to right reason, it is proper for there to be authority among humans, therefore etc. The major is clear because God gives right reason to humans so that they can execute those things which are right according to right reason. I prove the minor premise since that which is natural and expedient is according to right reason. But as the Philosopher says in the first book of the Politics, in every ordered plurality it is natural and expedient that one preside and others are subjects. But this is precisely what the concept of rulership (praelatio) consists in.
And this is confirmed because in all natural things we see that inferior things are ruled by superior things and a multitude is reduced to one. But custom just as art ought to imitate nature.

But in the second and third sense, that is with respect to the mode of acquiring dominion and with respect to the use of dominion already acquired, I say the following, that if such things are done in an ordered way and according to the right demands of the law, that is with rightful conditions and circumstances observed in the acquisition and use of rulership (praelatio), the rulership or principality is from God. But if the aforesaid are not observed, then rulership and principality of this type, although they are from God with respect to nature and the entity of the acts, just as other evil things are also from God, as has been proven above, nevertheless they are not from God with respect to their deformity and perversion of the act. For, in these cases, mortal sin is committed which is not able to be from God, but from the evil will of men. When in such cases it is said,
They set up kings, but not from me, they made princes and I did not know
that is without approving knowledge.

And through the aforesaid distinction the response to some common objections is clear, namely, that when it is said that some rulers are perverse, or some are usurped, or some are justly taken away, but just as, what God has joined together let no man separate, so that what someone has from God, or what is given to someone by God, by law this should not be taken away from them by man. For all these objections and those like them are only compelling either with respect to an inordinate mode of acquiring rulership or with respect to an inordinate use, for even if someone has justly acquired dominion, nevertheless they are able to use it so perversely that this dominion is lawfully taken away from them.

With respect to the second part of the article it should be said that an infidel has either justly acquired their dominion and used it in an appropriate way, or unjustly acquired their dominion, or granted that their dominion has been justly acquired, nevertheless they have used it in an unjust and inappropriate way.

In the first mode, I say that Christians ought to be obedient to this type of ruler, even though they are an infidel, unless in some mode they were justly liberated from this servitude, for example by a superior ruler, who has full dominion over the infidel lord. But in the second and third mode, I say that they are not obliged to obey such an infidel lord.

I prove this first in the following way, that which someone has justly acquired is unjustly taken from them unless they have misused it. But this infidel, as it is supposed, has justly acquired their dominion and has not abused it, therefore, etc.

Further, the Blessed Peter speaking about Christians says,
Servants be subject to your masters with all fear, not to the good and gentle alone, but even to the harsh .

Further the Apostle says,
Let thus under the yoke of servitude consider their masters worthy of every honor . And the gloss explains that the word yoke of the those ruling means the yoke of infidels.
Again it is said, Let everyone be subject to the higher powers

Further, divine law (ius) which is from grace and christian faith, does not destroy that which is from human law (ius) and from natural reason. But the distinction between believer and infidel is from the divine law, but just dominion is from human law and natural reason, therefore, etc. The minor is clear from the preceding. The major is proved because just as grace does not destroy human nature, but perfects it, so neither does the divine law destroy that which is from human law and is born from human reason. Nor consequently, does the distinction between believer and infidel destroy dominion or the rulership of an infidel lord which he has over a believing subject.
Nevertheless some doctors say that the church through its authority is justly able to take dominion of this type -- where a infidel has rule over a Christian people -- from such a ruler.
First because the infidel, owing to their infidelity deserves to have their power, which they have over those who have become sons of God.

Further, the Savior says,
If the son has liberated you, you are free indeed . But the Son of has God, through his own blood, has redeemed and liberated anyone who has been baptized.

Further, the Savior says, that children are free from tribute, but to all who are reborn in Christ,
who are not born of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but are born from God , power has been given, as they are the children of God, according to the verse: As many as received him, to them he gave the power to become children of God
Further, when the causes ceases, the effect ceases, but sin which is the cause of servitude, ceases through baptism, therefore etc.

Further, what has absolves something from a greater binding is also able to absolve from lesser binding, but faith absolves from the bond of marriage, by which a believer was bound before he received the faith with an unbeliever which indeed seems to be a greater and more intimate bond than the bond of servitude because it was instituted by God in paradise. Likewise about this the Savior says in the Gospel: what God has joined, let no man separate. Therefore, the faithful person is rightly absolved from the bond to an unbelieving lord.

But always preserving better judgment, I do not hold this to be true. For one who is not under the jurisdiction of the church, unless they sin against the church in some other way, cannot be justly punished by the church, except in the single matter that they do not hold the faith of the church. And it is assumed that this person has not sinned against the church in any way, except in the single matter that they do not hold the faith of the church. And the lord is severely punished in this, that jurisdiction over his own dominion, which he has over his own servants, is taken away from him.

Furthermore, no infidel who has never been subject to the faith of the church should be forcibly compelled to accept the faith of the church. However, if the church were to free someone who has newly come to the faith from the servitude they were held in by an infidel lord, such a lord would be forcibly compelled to accept the faith, because any of his servants could convert to the faith, and thus he would lose his entire dominion unless he accepted the Christian faith.

Perhaps it will be stated, as is evident from the ecclesiastical statute concerning the Jews, that if any servant of the Jews becomes a Christian, they are immediately freed from servitude, whether they were born into it (that is, a native-born slave) or whether they were purchased for servitude.
Furthermore, if such a Christian were to remain under the yoke of this infidel prince, then that infidel lord could compel such a subject to abandon the faith of Christ and blaspheme Christ.

I respond that it is otherwise with the Jews and other infidels, for the Jews, due to their own demerit, were reduced to servitude by the Roman princes and made their own servants. For a servant is so called from being preserved, because, having been justly captured in war and able to be killed by the prince, he is spared, and thus he and his posterity are reduced to servitude. This is what happened to the Jews through Titus and Vespasian. Therefore, when over time the Roman princes became Christians, the Roman Church, in favor of the faith, can set free the Jewish servants who have converted to the faith, because the Jews themselves and their possessions are subject to the authority of the Church through the favor of the Roman Emperors, who granted this to the Church. However, this does not apply to other infidels.

To the second argument, it must be said that if an infidel prince were to force a faithful subject to deny the faith, he would be abusing his power, and for this reason, he would deserve to lose it. Moreover, a just war could be waged against him and against his dominion by the Church and all Christians, to the extent that not only could his subjects be justly liberated from his rule, but the person of such a prince could also be justly reduced to servitude or even deprived of his position.
To the first argument for that opinion, it must be said that unless the unbelieving prince abuses his power in some other way, he does not deserve to lose it due to his unbelief alone.

To be said secondly, it must be stated that those words of Christ can be understood to refer to the freedom with which Christians have been liberated from the servitude of the Mosaic law, as regards the observance of ceremonial precepts. They can also be understood to refer to the freedom with which we have been liberated from sin and the servitude of the devil.

To the third point, it must be said that Christ is referring there to the sons of the Apostles, who possessed nothing of the goods of this world, as Peter testifies, saying, Behold, we have left everything and followed you. And therefore, they were not bound to pay the tribute. But to the Jews, who possessed the goods of the world, Christ said the same thing, Render to Caesar what is Caesar's, and to God what is God's. As if to say, You ought to give tribute from the temporal things that you possess.

To the fourth point, it should be said that although through grace, charity, and also through the Catholic faith, which a Christian receives in baptism, the soul is freed from the evil of guilt, the body is not freed from the evil of punishment. For the baptized dies, just as the unbaptized, and we are not freed from the debt of justice through faith. Nevertheless, it is just to obey a prince, even if he is unbelieving, who has justly obtained and justly and orderly exercises his dominion.

To the fifth point, it should be said that if one of the spouses converts to the faith while the other remains an infidel, if the infidel consents to live with the faithful one without disturbing them and without drawing them to infidelity and without blaspheming the Creator, then the faithful one is not released from the bond of matrimony. However, if the infidel does not want to cohabitate with the faithful one unless they are drawn to infidelity and the Creator is blasphemed, then the infidel loses their right to the faithful person due to their own fault, and consequently, the faithful one is justly released from the infidel. This has been more fully explained in book 4. And in the same way, if an infidel prince demands nothing from a faithful subject beyond what they are owed by law, then the subject is obligated to obey. However, if the prince wants to force the subject to do things that are against God and against the salvation of their soul, then the infidel prince loses the right they had over such a subject.
Secondly, I say that if such a prince has unjustly obtained this kind of dominion, then the subjects are not bound to obey him; and they can justly withdraw from him.
Because it is justly taken away from the unjust possessor what he possesses unjustly: but such a Tyrant possesses this kind of dominion unjustly, as is supposed, therefore, etc.

Thirdly, I say that, given that an infidel prince has justly acquired his dominion, if he nonetheless uses such dominion unjustly, for example to blaspheme the Creator or to hinder his subjects with regard to those things that pertain to the Christian faith, he once again deserves to lose such dominion.

And although this conclusion is evident from the preceding statements, I can nonetheless persuade it in this way: whenever the same subject is bound to two lords, one as a simple superior and the other as an inferior, if the inferior prince compels such a subject to dissent from the loyalty to the superior lord, then such a prince has, according to the laws and rights, lost jurisdiction over such a subject, and such a subject is no longer obligated to obey him. But God is the supreme lord and most universal emperor, with respect to whom every prince of this world is inferior; therefore, etc.

To address the main argument, it must be said that Blessed John does not intend to say through those words that some sin, no matter how great, is totally unforgivable as long as a person lives in this world. Instead, he intends to say that it is very difficult to obtain remission for such heinous sins. Therefore, such a sinner is not led to worthy repentance by the prayer of just any average Christian, but only by the prayer of the excellent and most devout faithful. It could also be said that Blessed John understands the sin unto death to be the sin against the Holy Spirit, due to the circumstance of final impenitence. For where it is certain that someone has departed this life in mortal sin without repentance, it would not be proper to pray for them according to common law, because such a person is outside the state of meriting, in which state our Savior, who lives and reigns forever, preserves us for the journey of our present pilgrimage, until He leads us to the homeland of blessed fruition, the Savior of all who are to be saved, who lives and reigns forever and ever, Amen.
